data.event: The central settlement in town, where 4,769 people resided at the 2010 census, is defined as the Newport census-designated place (CDP) and is located next to the Sugar River at the junction of New Hampshire routes 10 and 11.
Granted in 1753 by Colonial Governor Benning Wentworth, the town was named Grenville after George Grenville, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and brother-in-law of William Pitt.
It was first settled in 1763 by pioneers from North Killingworth, Connecticut.

event.title: treatment by the state government far beyond the mountains, Newport in 1781

data.event: But dissatisfied with treatment by the state government far beyond the mountains, Newport in 1781 joined 33 other towns along the Connecticut River and seceded from New Hampshire to join Vermont.
George Washington, however, would dissolve their union with Vermont in 1782, and the towns rejoined New Hampshire.
